stem: A client is admitted to the trauma unit after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with a suspected T2 spinal cord injury. Based on the documentation in the Hemodynamic & Autonomic Stability Log, which complication is the client experiencing?

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing **neurogenic shock (a1)**. Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension and bradycardia. In this case, the client's blood pressure is 74/38 mmHg (hypotension) and heart rate is 44 bpm (bradycardia). The skin is pink, warm, and dry due to vasodilation caused by the loss of sympathetic tone below the level of the spinal cord injury.
clinicalPearls: Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension, bradycardia, and warm, dry skin.
Treatment for neurogenic shock includes vasopressors (to increase blood pressure) and atropine (to increase heart rate).
Hypovolemic shock presents with tachycardia and cool, clammy skin.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting hypovolemic shock (a2) because the client was involved in a motor vehicle collision.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Assess the client's heart rate. In hypovolemic shock, the heart rate is typically elevated (tachycardia) to compensate for the decreased blood volume. In neurogenic shock, the heart rate is decreased (bradycardia) due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation.

mnemonic.title: Neuro-Normal
mnemonic.expansion: Neurogenic shock is the only type of shock where the skin feels 'Normal' (pink/warm) while the blood pressure is low.

exhibits.title: Physical Assessment
exhibits.content: Current: Skin is pink, warm, and dry to the touch throughout. No signs of active hemorrhage noted on secondary survey. Capillary refill is 4 seconds. Client is alert but sluggish.

exhibits.title: Injury Context
exhibits.content: Confirmed: Complete transection of the spinal cord at the T2 level. Loss of all sympathetic innervation below the level of the injury.
